results.title: Nice coloured girls
results.brief_description: Nice Coloured Girls contrasts the relationship between Australian First nations women and white men in the past and the present. The film juxtaposes contemporary images of black women taking advantage of a white man with voice over extracts from early journals of white settlers and sailors, in order to question the validity of conventional white history and to deny the image of First Nations people as passive and powerless.

results.title: Bushed
results.brief_description: An animated story concerning a displaced First Nations person and an out-of-place kangaroo who meet and decide to go ‘bush’, only to discover that they are intruders on their own land. A satire of life as an Australian First Nations person during the resources boom of the 1970’s, “Bushed” explores problems faced by First Nations peoples seeking employment, the ethics of tourism, slaughtering of kangaroos for pet food, and European denial of prior ownership by First Nations. This program carries a strong environmental message of the impact of colonisation on our native fauna.

results.title: Catch of the day
results.creator_credit: Australian Film Commission, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School and Sarah Watt
results.brief_description: The bright, beautiful and spontaneous ocean is something to wallow in. A young girl plays in the ocean and with the fishes. A dashing surfer rides up on his white steed and declares ‘I’ve come - you’ll never have to chop onions again!’ Jane wakes up from her dream (or was it a nightmare?) Working at the fish market, she endures the sexual innuendo and double entendres from male customers and fellow workers alike. When matters come to a head, she cleverly takes the situation into her own hands and offers a unique solution to unsolicited sexual advances… An impressionistic animation.

results.title: A Feeling of self worth
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Vandalism Task Force and Robin Young
results.brief_description: A feeling of self worth describes the approach taken at Monterey and the positive impact this has had on the school. Present and former staff and the parents of former students talk about the school as it used to be and the improvements that have been made.

results.title: Conservation tillage protecting our greatest asset
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Protecting Our Greatest Asset”.
It should be noted that this video is made by a chemical company that manufactures herbicides. Intensive cropping and continual cultivation stresses the Australian soil dramatically. This video looks at alternative methods to soil tillage by machinery, namely herbicides. Crops which require no tillage as conservation are also discussed.

results.title: A Colour Box
results.brief_description: The purely abstract A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement.

constellations_other.name: Circling expanded cinema
constellations_other.description: Explore how expanded cinema like Lis Rhodes' Light Music connects to film composers, experimental materials and virtual reality.

results.description: The purely abstract “A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.
description_for_label: The purely abstract “A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.

results.title: Rhythm
results.brief_description:
Originally planned as a work for Chrysler Corporation’s weekly television program, ‘Rhythm’ presents a montage of the factory workers, machinery and materials on a car production assembly line.
Lye has edited his footage with a staccato feel that he has matched with the percussive music used for the soundtrack.
Although rejected by Chrysler, the film won first prize in the television category in the 1957 New York Art Directors’ Festival but was subsequently disqualified because it had never been broadcast.

results.title: Words and silk
results.creator_credit: Philip Tyndall, John Cruthers and Kangaroo Films
results.brief_description: A two part program about the life and works of Australian fiction writer, Gerald Murnane. Pt. 1. The imaginary and real world of Gerald Murnane (41 min.) The first part explores his imaginary world and presents images both of Murnane’s childhood in Victoria during the 1940’s and of his interests, particularly his obsession with horseracing. Pt. 2. The real and imaginary world of Gerald Murnane (45 min.) In the second part Murnane discusses his writing style and reads extracts from Tamarisk Row to show how he weaves his interests and obsessions into his work.

results.title: Looking at plants
results.creator_credit: John Bird, Jim Harris and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Filmed in the Sherbrooke Forest Park, Australflora Nursery, Victoria, and shows glimpses of the plant and insect life which abound there. No narration, music only.
